summary:
: India is a megadiverse country with 8.6% of all mammal species, 13.7% of bird species, 7.9% of reptile species, 6% of amphibian species, 12.2% of fish species, and 6.0% of all flowering plant species.

India's forest cover is 713,789 km2 (275,595 sq mi), which is 21.71% of the country's total land area.

India has a growth rate of 7.5% and is currently experiencing its worst recession in decades.

The Indian subcontinent is home to a vast array of unique tree species, each used in various ways across different contexts and in different parts of the world. India is a supercontinent thatGondwana split in two], and the Andes.

Lima is an Inca god of theSouth America region, as well as theAndes.

Lima is also the name of an Inca god of the North America region.

The above-mentioned factors arevolving together have caused India's endemism in animals to drop to less than 10% of its pre-Himalaya level.

India contains 172 IUCN-designated threatened animal species, or 2.9% of endangered forms. These include the endangered Bengal tiger and the Ganges river dolphin

The India white-rumped vulture is a highly endangered species of vireo that is likely to become the first species in the world to perish from roads andcattle farming.:

The system of national parks and protected areas, first established in 1935, was expanded significantly after the US Supreme Court ruled in 1938 that federal land should be used for conservation and not administration.

India has passed the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972, and the Forest Conservation Act, 1980, regulating the management of wildlife; the Institute for Conservation Research (ICR) was founded in 1984 and amendments were made in 1988. India is also registered under the Ramsar Convention.
